title: Are GMOs good or bad?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why genetic engineering is considered different from selective breeding?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic engineering is slower than selective breeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic engineering is more precise than selective breeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic engineering eliminates the factor of lucky hits.

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic engineering is only used in medical applications.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "terminator seeds" in the context of GMOs?

options.label: A
options.text: Seeds that are resistant to pests.

options.label: C
options.text: Seeds that can be used in multiple growing seasons.

options.label: D
options.text: Seeds that are genetically modified to produce more fruit.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern regarding the unintentional spreading of engineered DNA from GM crops?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will lead to the extinction of non-GM crops.

options.label: B
options.text: That it will contaminate the food supply.

options.label: C
options.text: That it will lead to the development of pesticide-resistant pests.

options.label: D
options.text: That it will cause gene flow and introduce unwanted characteristics into traditional crops.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of eating GMO plants compared to non-GM plants?

options.label: A
options.text: Eating GMO plants is more risky than eating non-GM plants.

options.label: B
options.text: Eating GMO plants is no more risky than eating non-GM plants.

options.label: C
options.text: Eating GMO plants is less nutritious than eating non-GM plants.

options.label: D
options.text: Eating GMO plants is more expensive than eating non-GM plants.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of BT crops?

options.label: D
options.text: To produce a protein that destroys the digestive system of specific insect pests.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of the GMO debate?

options.label: A
options.text: That GMOs are not effective in reducing pesticide use.

options.label: B
options.text: That GMOs are not safe for human consumption.

options.label: C
options.text: That GMOs are a tool of big corporations controlling the food supply.

options.label: D
options.text: That GMOs are not environmentally friendly.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a positive outcome of using GM crops?

options.label: A
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh led to a significant increase in pesticide use.

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh led to a significant reduction in pesticide use and improved health and income for farmers.

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh led to a significant decrease in crop yields.

options.label: D
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh had no significant impact on farmers.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential benefits of using GMOs in agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the use of fertilizers in the developed world.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the use of fertilizers in the developed world.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the shortage of fertilizers in developing countries.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the shortage of fertilizers in developing countries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential of GMOs in mitigating climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no potential in mitigating climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a limited potential in mitigating climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a significant potential in mitigating climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a potential to exacerbate climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using GMOs in agriculture compared to traditional methods?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more expensive than traditional methods.

options.label: B
options.text: They are less effective than traditional methods.

options.label: C
options.text: They can produce more food with less land and resources.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more environmentally friendly than traditional methods.

title: How the world's first metro system was built - Christian Wolmar

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the first subway system in the world, which opened in London in 1863?

options.label: C
options.text: The City and South London Railway

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with first thinking of putting railways under the ground in London?
What was the name of the system used to build the Metropolitan Railway, which involved digging a huge trench, constructing a tunnel, and then refilling the hole?
What was the main problem that the Metropolitan Railway aimed to solve in London?
How did the Greathead Shield machine allow for the construction of new subway lines in London?

options.label: A
options.text: By reducing the number of workers needed

options.label: B
options.text: By allowing for deeper tunnels to be dug

options.label: C
options.text: By enabling the construction of tunnels under buildings without disturbing the surface

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the cost of construction

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Metropolitan Railway on the development of new suburbs in London?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the decline of existing suburbs

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in the construction of new department stores

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the growth of new suburbs around the stations

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the development of new suburbs

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why the "cut and cover" technique was no longer used for building new subway lines in London by the late 1880s?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the city had become too dense with buildings, sewers, and electric cables

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Greathead Shield machine was not available

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Metropolitan Railway in the development of modern urban transportation systems?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first subway system to use electric trains

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first subway system to use a tunnel-boring machine

options.label: C
options.text: It marked the beginning of the development of modern urban transportation systems

options.label: D
options.text: It was a major innovation in urban transportation that paved the way for future developments

multiple-choice.question: How did the construction of the Metropolitan Railway affect the development of other cities around the world?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the decline of other cities

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in the construction of new department stores

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the development of similar subway systems in other cities

options.label: D
options.text: It inspired other cities to develop their own subway systems

multiple-choice.question: What is the legacy of Charles Pearson and the Metropolitan Railway in the development of modern urban transportation systems?

options.label: A
options.text: They are remembered as pioneers in the development of electric trains

options.label: B
options.text: They are credited with inventing the tunnel-boring machine

options.label: C
options.text: They are recognized as the first to build a subway system in a major city

options.label: D
options.text: They are thanked for getting the world started on the right track in developing modern urban transportation systems

multiple-choice.question: Who was the powerful hermit in the story?

options.label: C
options.text: Whoever first brought back a glass full of morning dew

options.text: By collecting the morning dew directly from a flower

title: The rise and fall of the Byzantine Empire - Leonora Neville

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Constantine, the first Christian emperor, move the capital of the Roman Empire to a new city called Constantinople?

options.label: A
options.text: The sack of Rome by the Visigoths

options.label: B
options.text: The conquest of the Empire's western provinces by barbarians

options.label: D
options.text: The unpaid army's aggression on Constantinople, led by the Crusaders

multiple-choice.question: How did the Byzantine Empire's artists innovate?

options.text: They innovated by creating vast mosaics and ornate marble carvings.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They only created fictional accounts of historical events.

title: What causes body odor? - Mel Rosenberg

options.label: A
options.text: To secrete mainly water and salt

options.label: C
options.text: To secrete sweat full of proteins and fats

options.text: Only the nutrients provided by the glands

options.text: The resident microbial populations in the armpit and the nutrients provided by the glands

options.label: B
options.text: To secrete sweat full of proteins and fats

options.label: D
options.text: To break down proteins and fats in apocrine sweat into odor-causing compounds

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the intensity of body odor

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To cement social bonds and provide a means of chemical communication

options.label: D
options.text: To secrete sweat full of proteins and fats

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It is a common genetic trait

options.label: D

options.label: A

title: How do fish make electricity? - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the explorer who witnessed a swarm of electric eels leap out of the water to defend themselves against oncoming horses?
**Comprehension**: How do weakly electric fish produce electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: By using their brains to generate a magnetic field

options.label: B
options.text: By pumping out sodium and potassium ions to maintain a positive charge outside and negative charge inside

options.label: C
options.text: By using their tails to generate a small voltage

options.label: D
options.text: By using their nervous system to send a signal to their electric organs

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If you were to design an experiment to test the ability of weakly electric fish to navigate, what would be a suitable control group?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of fish with their electric organs removed

options.label: B
options.text: A group of fish with their eyes removed

options.label: C
options.text: A group of fish with their nervous system damaged

options.label: D
options.text: A group of fish with their tails removed

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What is the key to the ability of strongly electric fish to produce powerful electric discharges?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of their electric organs

options.label: B
options.text: The number of electrocytes in their electric organs

options.label: C
options.text: The coordination of nerve signals to arrive at each cell at exactly the same time

options.label: D
options.text: The type of ions used to generate the electric discharge

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How might the ability of electric fish to produce electricity be used in a real-world application?

options.label: A
options.text: To power a small electric motor

options.label: B
options.text: To generate a magnetic field for medical imaging

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new type of battery

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new form of underwater communication

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are some potential drawbacks to the use of electric fish for underwater communication?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of interference from other electrical signals

options.label: B
options.text: The limited range of the communication system

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for the fish to become disoriented or lost

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of the fish being electrocuted by their own signals

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the fish with an elongated chin called a schnauzenorgan that's riddled with electroreceptors?
**Comprehension**: How do strongly electric fish use their electric discharges to hunt their prey?

options.label: A
options.text: By emitting a single strong pulse to stun the prey

options.label: B
options.text: By emitting two or three strong pulses to stimulate the prey's muscles

options.label: C
options.text: By emitting a volley of fast, high-voltage discharges to cause intense muscle contractions

options.label: D
options.text: By emitting a series of weak pulses to wear down the prey

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What is the likely reason why strongly electric fish are able to withstand their own electric discharges?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of their electric organs is too small to cause harm

options.label: B
options.text: The current passes out of their bodies too quickly

options.label: C
options.text: Special proteins shield the electric organs

options.label: D
options.text: The electric discharges are too weak to cause harm

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are some potential areas of further research in the field of electric fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of new types of electric organs

options.label: B
options.text: The use of electric fish for underwater communication

options.label: C
options.text: The study of the neural mechanisms underlying electric discharge production

options.label: A
options.text: They are a source of foreshadowing

title: Where do math symbols come from? - John David Walters

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the book "The Whetstone of Witte" to teach English students algebra?
What was Robert Recorde's solution to avoid writing the words "is equal to" over and over in his book?

options.label: A
options.text: He replaced them with the words "are equal to"

options.label: B
options.text: He replaced them with two parallel horizontal line segments

options.label: C
options.text: He replaced them with a single vertical line segment

options.label: D
options.text: He replaced them with a multiplication sign

multiple-choice.question: Why did Robert Recorde choose two parallel horizontal line segments to represent equality?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a common symbol in ancient mathematics

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a unique symbol that no two things can be more equal

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a simple and easy-to-write symbol

options.label: D
options.text: Because it reflected the idea that no two things can be more equal

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a symbol that communicates meaning through form, as mentioned in the transcript?
Why did Christian Kramp introduce the exclamation mark for factorials?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a common symbol in ancient mathematics

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a unique symbol that no two things can be more equal

options.label: C
options.text: Because he needed a shorthand for expressions like 5!

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a symbol that he liked

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a symbol that is used to represent operations, as mentioned in the transcript?
How does the multiplication sign condense repeated operations into a single expression?

options.label: A
options.text: By indicating that a number should be multiplied by itself

options.label: B
options.text: By indicating that a number should be added to itself

options.label: C
options.text: By indicating that a number should be multiplied by another number

options.label: D
options.text: By indicating that a number should be divided by another number

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a symbol that provides succinct instructions about how to perform calculations, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: D
options.text: An expression that shows a sequence of operations

multiple-choice.question: Why would an alien civilization probably have a totally different set of symbols, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they would have a different language

options.label: B
options.text: Because they would have a different way of thinking

options.label: C
options.text: Because they would have a different set of mathematical concepts

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a symbol that may correspond directly to ours, as mentioned in the transcript?
